summary: Arya is so under appreciated after this episode
body:
Arya is so under appreciated after this episode

Honestly why can’t people just be more grateful of my bby and living legend Arya mfing Stark like if she isn’t your fave character then she saved your fave characters ass when she killed the night king why can’t ppl just give her credit instead of just casting her aside and trying to discredit her like I get so annoyed when ppl do that.

tags: panicking like nobody even knows it because we COULDN'T SEE
is ghost okay!? somebody find ghost!
bby theon i miss you already
title: The Battle of Winter
body:
Tumblr GoT stan: full of emotions editing content and cranking up that brightness and contrast because they couldn’t see 90% of the episode

Smart-ass GoT stan: well you know the episode is called The Long Night

Every GoT stan: spent 80 minutes panicking, hyperventilating and squinting because nobody could really see who was fighting who…

blog.name: annamarcellipalmer
blog.title: DeppieT
blog.description: Writes stories she hopes are readable; obsesses over books and shows; makes all sorts of fanart; prefers cats to most people.

title: Post-S8Ep3 Braime Rant
body:
(Ahead there be spoilers. And a lengthy, ugh, rant.)


Hello again, fellow shippers and GoT enthusiasts. Last week I said I would take everything back with regards to D&D if they didn’t kill off one or both my babies, and here I am, admitting I was wrong. And believe me when I say that I’ve never in my life been happier about being wrong.

Jaime and Brienne survived the great war. We didn’t get to see nearly enough of their sexy, back-to-back fighting, and it took a whole lot of plot armor for both of them, but they got to see the day after all the same. Now, not to lie, I expected some more badassery, especially from the first female knight in the seven goddamn kingdoms. It annoys me that, out of all the POV characters that actually appear in the show, Brienne is so under-utilized, and I sincerely hope she gets a moment of absolute lady-knight glory sometime in the remaining three episodes.

Did I just say “three episodes”? How far we’ve come! From trying to hack down one another to defending one another, from “Is that a woman?” to “I came North because… coughIloveyoucough I am not much of a fighter, but-”, Jaime and Brienne have become the quintessential slow-burn romance of modern high fantasy, and we now only have three episodes left until we are provided with some sort of closure to their conjoint arc. D&D impressed me by subverting my expectations and letting both live, but, seeing as last episode was more or less somebody’s well-written fanfic, I am completely in the dark with regards to where everything can go from now on. Therefore, and since this is what Tumblr is mostly about, let there be mad speculation:

  1. Worst case scenario (or, how I punched my TV in my free time and why you could do it, too):

Listen, I don’t believe this will happen, but better be prepared for horror than have an actual heart attack, yes? Jaime obviously rode north because of Brienne’s “fuck loyalty” remark, followed by the explanation that, yes, family and houses are one thing, but this -aka the fight against the AotD- is about survival. It is, furthermore, quite safe to assume, given Jaime’s “I wanna die in the arms of the woman I love” mentality, that he rode north to fight, and die for, Brienne. I doubt survival was in his initial plans, and thus I am not sure he’s completely come to terms with the fact that now, the only war left is the one against his -pregnant- sister.

Oh, sweet mother of bad characterization, could this be a legit case scenario? We all know Jaime Don’t-Ask-Me-To-Betray-My-Family fooking Lannister has an extremely warped sense of duty, and the fact that he never got to be a father for his three deceased children scares me a bit. Let’s face it, a pregnancy is no small thing, even if it occurs within the womb of a woman we all love to hate. It won’t be the first time we’ve seen him relapse, and we know that the fact that he might get killed the moment he approaches the Keep probably won’t deter the fool one bit (he charged at a dragon by himself, not the sharpest tool in the shed). Cersei’s pregnancy hasn’t been mentioned without reason, and unless that reason is somehow Tyrion (I hope not, you absolute, absolute DwILF) Jaime being trapped between two worlds, and two women, could provide some much-needed (and, ugh, badly written) drama for his arc.

The case against? Literally common logic, but let’s scratch that and take a look at the facts. That baby is dead. I mean, technically it isn’t, but there is no way Cersei can realistically win the war without burning KL to the ground, and I don’t think Jaime, whose arc is one of redemption, could live with himself after that. So, riding North, he must have made peace with the idea that Cersei and her unborn child are, for the sake of humanity if anything, toast. Furthermore, the onslaught of Braime content we were graced with in ep.2 now feels less like a kiss of death and more like groundwork, for, what, exactly? More platonic camaraderie, perhaps. Perhaps D&D’s reading comprehension skills are worse than mine, and English is my second language, so go figure. 

Where could it go? Shakespearean twaddle. You know, the kind of dramatic tomfoolery only Shakespear himself was good at. Incestuous lovers dying in each other’s arms. Jaime realizing a moment too late that team Tarth is where it’s at. Brienne ending up alone or with the comic relief character because idiocy is all the rage these days. Unlikely.


2) Best case scenario (or, there is no fucking way they are going down that route, but if they do, I’ll travel all the way to HBO and french-kiss every magnificent bastard I come across):

The word here is groundwork. Jaime interrupts his conversation with Tyrion to go stare longingly at Brienne; we get a shit ton of Pride and Prejudice parallels, complete with hopeless banter in the stead of actual flirting; Jaime trails off after saying “I came North, because..” so that every idiot within a hundred-mile radius can add two-plus-two and come up with the inevitable answer to the million dollar question; Tyrion raises his eyebrows when he sees Jaime’s reaction to Brienne; Jaime completely smashes our collective ovaries by saying “arise, Brienne of Tarth” in a way that could make deserts wet.

Why were our eyes blessed with all of that? Up until ep.3 we thought it was D&D’s not-so-subtle way of flagging imminent deaths. But that was not the case, was it? Instead, we saw Jaime and Brienne fight back to back, in a scene that very much paralleled their bridge duel from a few years ago, as if to provide a belated answer to Brienne’s question to Catelyn Stark ( “who wants to die defending a Lannister? “ A wild Brienne appears! She’s VERY effective.)

An optimist might say that, given how little screen time there was left, everything happened for a reason yet to be disclosed. Episode four is kept under wraps completely. We know that, as an aftermath episode, it will be character driven, and as it happens, the last character driven episode left many hanging ifs with regards to Team Lannistarth. If either of them is ever going to open up and admit romantic feelings, having come face-to-face with death is most likely to do the trick. If there is a time for sweet, sweet lovemaking, that time is now. Tick f*ing tock, you lovelorn idiots. Now kiss.

The obvious caveat here is once more characterization. Jaime believes he has shit for honour, he literally cannot believe his eyes when he realizes Brienne of all people is happy to be knighted by him. So he probably thinks he drags Brienne down with him if he makes the move. Brienne, on her end, is clueless. Despite her trust in Jaime she expected the knighting to be a farce, not to mention she was flummoxed to see Jaime abstain from insults. Pragmatically speaking, there is no way Jaime can convince her that, he, renowned knight, previously the best fighter in Westeros, ridiculously attractive and once heir to  motherf*ing Casterly Rock, is interested in a relationship with Brienne the Beauty, least traditional female ever and recurring joke amongst male fighters.

How it could all go? The ending, as per GRRM’s words, will be bittersweet. Since he’s never taken the most obvious route, I doubt the sweet end of this arrangement is reserved for Jonerys ( a pity, but I suspect it will be tragic and satisfying for the shippers). Here’s a bonus for you: Jaime Lannister has the worst survival foreshadowing out of every GoT character. He is name number one on everyone’s season 8 death pool. Perhaps this is exactly why he could live up to the very end. Therefore, if he does, and if Brienne is still around, we can dream of the two riding off into the sunset, romantic Braime theme playing, and living the rest of their days on Tarth, or as Ser Brienne and Ser Jaime Lannister, wardens of the west. Yes, we can picture all of that.

Of course, we can also put our fingers in an electrical outlet. Doesn’t mean we won’t regret it.


3) Middle ground, realistic outcome. Or: I have no idea what’s on your mind, D&D. Leak the season before I piss meself.

There, I said it. We have no idea how all this will go down. But since this post is about mad speculation, I will conjure up some middle ground Braime endgames for your reading pleasure.

  • Episode four will reap what was sown in episode 2. Episode 2 was clearly meant to make it clear that something romantic is brewing. So, we get a post-battle heart-to-heart about the way death made Jaime realize he can’t afford to lose any more time, and how, after this new war, they could plan for a life, together. Brienne does not initially believe him, but similarly, facing death has made her wary of losing any opportunity that comes her way. We get one of the three: a kiss, OathSex, or a marriage proposal/ceremony (tons of foreshadowing in both the books and the show: Book Brienne dreams of the lannister sigil on the cloak of the man she is to marry; show Jaime is told he cannot marry Cersei a split second before Brienne passes by). Caveat: This is GoT, and we cannot have nice things. So Jaime, for closure to his Cersei arc, goes south, tries to kill Cersei, and ultimately goes out in a blaze of glory, taking her with him. Kingslayer and Queenslayer. Winner: Poetic Justice. Loser: One (1) Lady Ser being widowed.
  • Episode four will be underwhelming and we will never get a definite answer on the Braime question. Don’t get me wrong. Everyone and their mother knows they love each other, but they clearly have been pining from afar, believing their object of adoration is out of reach, or simply not interested. So, while it is obvious that Braime exists, and that the stupidest Lannister is no longer interested in Cersei, the show abstains from physical and/or romantic content between our favorite knights, and lets us decide for ourselves. There will be hints, perhaps, if Jaime does die trying to kill Cersei, he might tell his ex lover about Brienne, but nothing beyond that. Caveat: this season the writers have obviously tried to be more feminist, so I want to hope that they will abstain from the sexless romance between ugly woman and attractive man trope.
  • Episode four is the episode Bronn arrives at Winterfell and freaks every single viewer the f*ck out. He kills Jaime, causes a collective meltdown, but at least we get the “I wanna die in the arms of the woman I love” ending, complete with a confession. Bonus: Brienne kills Bronn. (I hope this doesn’t happen. I love my boy Bronn, first Braime shipper in the seven kingdoms and all around magnificent motherf*er.)
  • Episode four is still the episode Bronn arrives at Winterfell and freaks every single viewer the f*ck out, only that this time it is Brienne he takes down with him. Brienne wants to die defending a Lannister, and we get to see why Lysa Arrynn once cried out in disbelief: “You don’t fight with honor!” (Brienne does.) Consolation cookie: Jaime exclaiming something along the lines of “That was my wife you absolute sellsword!” before offing Bronn, one hand, in the name of love. (U2 music plays softly in the background). Caveat: Come on. The average fanfic is better than that.

 Soooo, that was it, that was every mad Braime scenario I would come up with. I hope you enjoyed reading, hopefully you might have even had a laugh or two. Feel free to share your own mad, mad  Braime scenarios! Hopefully one of us will guess the actual Braime endgame, and if not, no worries. We are only a week away from the answers. Or from nervous breakdown.

In D&D we (want to) trust.

(Ahead there be spoilers. And a lengthy, ugh, rant.)

We didn’t get to see nearly enough of their sexy, back-to-back fighting, and it took a whole lot of plot armor for both of them, but they got to see the day after all the same. Now, not to lie, I expected some more badassery, especially from the first female knight in the seven goddamn kingdoms. It annoys me that, out of all the POV characters that actually appear in the show, Brienne is so under-utilized, and I sincerely hope she gets a moment of absolute lady-knight glory sometime in the remaining three episodes.

Did I just say “three episodes”? How far we’ve come! From trying to hack down one another to defending one another, from “Is that a woman?” to “I came North because… coughIloveyoucough I am not much of a fighter, but-”, Jaime and Brienne have become the quintessential slow-burn romance of modern high fantasy, and we now only have three episodes left until we are provided with some sort of closure to their conjoint arc. D&D impressed me by subverting my expectations and letting both live, but, seeing as last episode was more or less somebody’s well-written fanfic, I am completely in the dark with regards to where everything can go from now on. Therefore, and since this is what Tumblr is mostly about, let there be mad speculation:

  1. Worst case scenario (or, how I punched my TV in my free time and why you could do it, too):

Listen, I don’t believe this will happen, but better be prepared for horror than have an actual heart attack, yes? Jaime obviously rode north because of Brienne’s “fuck loyalty” remark, followed by the explanation that, yes, family and houses are one thing, but this -aka the fight against the AotD- is about survival. It is, furthermore, quite safe to assume, given Jaime’s “I wanna die in the arms of the woman I love” mentality, that he rode north to fight, and die for, Brienne. I doubt survival was in his initial plans, and thus I am not sure he’s completely come to terms with the fact that now, the only war left is the one against his -pregnant- sister.

Oh, sweet mother of bad characterization, could this be a legit case scenario? We all know Jaime Don’t-Ask-Me-To-Betray-My-Family fooking Lannister has an extremely warped sense of duty, and the fact that he never got to be a father for his three deceased children scares me a bit. Let’s face it, a pregnancy is no small thing, even if it occurs within the womb of a woman we all love to hate. It won’t be the first time we’ve seen him relapse, and we know that the fact that he might get killed the moment he approaches the Keep probably won’t deter the fool one bit (he charged at a dragon by himself, not the sharpest tool in the shed). Cersei’s pregnancy hasn’t been mentioned without reason, and unless that reason is somehow Tyrion (I hope not, you absolute, absolute DwILF) Jaime being trapped between two worlds, and two women, could provide some much-needed (and, ugh, badly written) drama for his arc.

The case against? Literally common logic, but let’s scratch that and take a look at the facts. That baby is dead. I mean, technically it isn’t, but there is no way Cersei can realistically win the war without burning KL to the ground, and I don’t think Jaime, whose arc is one of redemption, could live with himself after that. So, riding North, he must have made peace with the idea that Cersei and her unborn child are, for the sake of humanity if anything, toast. Furthermore, the onslaught of Braime content we were graced with in ep.2 now feels less like a kiss of death and more like groundwork, for, what, exactly? More platonic camaraderie, perhaps. Perhaps D&D’s reading comprehension skills are worse than mine, and English is my second language, so go figure. 

Where could it go? Shakespearean twaddle. You know, the kind of dramatic tomfoolery only Shakespear himself was good at. Incestuous lovers dying in each other’s arms. Jaime realizing a moment too late that team Tarth is where it’s at. Brienne ending up alone or with the comic relief character because idiocy is all the rage these days. Unlikely.


2) Best case scenario (or, there is no fucking way they are going down that route, but if they do, I’ll travel all the way to HBO and french-kiss every magnificent bastard I come across):

The word here is groundwork. Jaime interrupts his conversation with Tyrion to go stare longingly at Brienne; we get a shit ton of Pride and Prejudice parallels, complete with hopeless banter in the stead of actual flirting; Jaime trails off after saying “I came North, because..” so that every idiot within a hundred-mile radius can add two-plus-two and come up with the inevitable answer to the million dollar question; Tyrion raises his eyebrows when he sees Jaime’s reaction to Brienne; Jaime completely smashes our collective ovaries by saying “arise, Brienne of Tarth” in a way that could make deserts wet.

Why were our eyes blessed with all of that? Up until ep.3 we thought it was D&D’s not-so-subtle way of flagging imminent deaths. But that was not the case, was it? Instead, we saw Jaime and Brienne fight back to back, in a scene that very much paralleled their bridge duel from a few years ago, as if to provide a belated answer to Brienne’s question to Catelyn Stark ( “who wants to die defending a Lannister? “ A wild Brienne appears! She’s VERY effective.)

An optimist might say that, given how little screen time there was left, everything happened for a reason yet to be disclosed. Episode four is kept under wraps completely. We know that, as an aftermath episode, it will be character driven, and as it happens, the last character driven episode left many hanging ifs with regards to Team Lannistarth. If either of them is ever going to open up and admit romantic feelings, having come face-to-face with death is most likely to do the trick. If there is a time for sweet, sweet lovemaking, that time is now. Tick f*ing tock, you lovelorn idiots. Now kiss.

The obvious caveat here is once more characterization. Jaime believes he has shit for honour, he literally cannot believe his eyes when he realizes Brienne of all people is happy to be knighted by him. So he probably thinks he drags Brienne down with him if he makes the move. Brienne, on her end, is clueless. Despite her trust in Jaime she expected the knighting to be a farce, not to mention she was flummoxed to see Jaime abstain from insults. Pragmatically speaking, there is no way Jaime can convince her that, he, renowned knight, previously the best fighter in Westeros, ridiculously attractive and once heir to  motherf*ing Casterly Rock, is interested in a relationship with Brienne the Beauty, least traditional female ever and recurring joke amongst male fighters.

How it could all go? The ending, as per GRRM’s words, will be bittersweet. Since he’s never taken the most obvious route, I doubt the sweet end of this arrangement is reserved for Jonerys ( a pity, but I suspect it will be tragic and satisfying for the shippers). Here’s a bonus for you: Jaime Lannister has the worst survival foreshadowing out of every GoT character. He is name number one on everyone’s season 8 death pool. Perhaps this is exactly why he could live up to the very end. Therefore, if he does, and if Brienne is still around, we can dream of the two riding off into the sunset, romantic Braime theme playing, and living the rest of their days on Tarth, or as Ser Brienne and Ser Jaime Lannister, wardens of the west. Yes, we can picture all of that.

Of course, we can also put our fingers in an electrical outlet. Doesn’t mean we won’t regret it.


3) Middle ground, realistic outcome. Or: I have no idea what’s on your mind, D&D. Leak the season before I piss meself.

There, I said it. We have no idea how all this will go down. But since this post is about mad speculation, I will conjure up some middle ground Braime endgames for your reading pleasure.

  • Episode four will reap what was sown in episode 2. Episode 2 was clearly meant to make it clear that something romantic is brewing. So, we get a post-battle heart-to-heart about the way death made Jaime realize he can’t afford to lose any more time, and how, after this new war, they could plan for a life, together. Brienne does not initially believe him, but similarly, facing death has made her wary of losing any opportunity that comes her way. We get one of the three: a kiss, OathSex, or a marriage proposal/ceremony (tons of foreshadowing in both the books and the show: Book Brienne dreams of the lannister sigil on the cloak of the man she is to marry; show Jaime is told he cannot marry Cersei a split second before Brienne passes by). Caveat: This is GoT, and we cannot have nice things. So Jaime, for closure to his Cersei arc, goes south, tries to kill Cersei, and ultimately goes out in a blaze of glory, taking her with him. Kingslayer and Queenslayer. Winner: Poetic Justice. Loser: One (1) Lady Ser being widowed.
  • Episode four will be underwhelming and we will never get a definite answer on the Braime question. Don’t get me wrong. Everyone and their mother knows they love each other, but they clearly have been pining from afar, believing their object of adoration is out of reach, or simply not interested. So, while it is obvious that Braime exists, and that the stupidest Lannister is no longer interested in Cersei, the show abstains from physical and/or romantic content between our favorite knights, and lets us decide for ourselves. There will be hints, perhaps, if Jaime does die trying to kill Cersei, he might tell his ex lover about Brienne, but nothing beyond that. Caveat: this season the writers have obviously tried to be more feminist, so I want to hope that they will abstain from the sexless romance between ugly woman and attractive man trope.
  • Episode four is the episode Bronn arrives at Winterfell and freaks every single viewer the f*ck out. He kills Jaime, causes a collective meltdown, but at least we get the “I wanna die in the arms of the woman I love” ending, complete with a confession. Bonus: Brienne kills Bronn. (I hope this doesn’t happen. I love my boy Bronn, first Braime shipper in the seven kingdoms and all around magnificent motherf*er.)
  • Episode four is still the episode Bronn arrives at Winterfell and freaks every single viewer the f*ck out, only that this time it is Brienne he takes down with him. Brienne wants to die defending a Lannister, and we get to see why Lysa Arrynn once cried out in disbelief: “You don’t fight with honor!” (Brienne does.) Consolation cookie: Jaime exclaiming something along the lines of “That was my wife you absolute sellsword!” before offing Bronn, one hand, in the name of love. (U2 music plays softly in the background). Caveat: Come on. The average fanfic is better than that.

 Soooo, that was it, that was every mad Braime scenario I would come up with. I hope you enjoyed reading, hopefully you might have even had a laugh or two. Feel free to share your own mad, mad  Braime scenarios! Hopefully one of us will guess the actual Braime endgame, and if not, no worries. We are only a week away from the answers. Or from nervous breakdown.

In D&D we (want to) trust.
trail.content:
(Ahead there be spoilers. And a lengthy, ugh, rant.)


Hello again, fellow shippers and GoT enthusiasts. Last week I said I would take everything back with regards to D&D if they didn’t kill off one or both my babies, and here I am, admitting I was wrong. And believe me when I say that I’ve never in my life been happier about being wrong.

Jaime and Brienne survived the great war. We didn’t get to see nearly enough of their sexy, back-to-back fighting, and it took a whole lot of plot armor for both of them, but they got to see the day after all the same. title: Speciale “Serie TV” – Game Of Thrones 8×03: i meme più divertenti
body:
The Long Night è stato uno degli episodi più memorabili ed epici di tutta la serie. Ciò non ha comunque fermato l'immancabile ondata di meme a tema. Diamo uno sguardo a quelli più divertenti!

Attenzione: la notte è buia e questo articolo pieno di spoiler

Torna puntualissimo come sempre l’appuntamento con i meme più divertenti del Trono di Spade. Terza puntata che, nonostante la delicata e concitata battaglia contro gli Estranei, non è stata esente da giudizi contrastanti e anche divertenti. Protagonisti dell’episodio la diretta Sky, causa di uno streaming pessimo, pieno di glitch e…

summary: what do you think about ppl trying to compare sansa and danys journeys? i see a lot of danita fans still upset at how sansa...
question: what do you think about ppl trying to compare sansa and danys journeys? i see a lot of danita fans still upset at how sansa "doesnt give her respect". I rlly dont understand why they expect these two to be buddy buddy. Female characters dont have to like each other esp when they have different goals and mindsets.
answer: It’s the same thing they’ve been doing for 2 years, demanding that Sansa worship Dany. They refused to consider Sansa’s position and where she’s coming from even though it’s very easy to understand. We’ve explained it over and over again to the point where even the locals are saying what we’ve been saying. They don’t care. They want people to worship Danito, they want her to be the protagonist, they want a boring black and white conflict less plot. It’s very annoying. Sansa shows Dany the amount of respect Dany showed her, Sansa told Dany her issues with her (food shortage and Northern independence) and Sansa made it clear to Tyrion that she’s not loyal to Dany. Meanwhile Dany is out here making sly threats

blog.description: "I don't think you were the mastermind. I don't think you're smart enough for it."

summary: Melisandre going to the battle and having to micromanage everyone because her vague hints at what they were supposed to do...
body: Melisandre going to the battle and having to micromanage everyone because her vague hints at what they were supposed to do weren’t picked up on and then still not telling them directly because she wants them to work it out for themselves is basically every shitty boss ever

blog.name: bmgmw
blog.title: it's all about perspective
blog.description: 27. F. Bi. Hodgepodge of AM, GoT, ODAAT, AWAE, GMW, B99, TGP and whatever else I end up getting sucked into 📺ask box open :)

summary: do you ship Sansa and Tyrion?
question: do you ship Sansa and Tyrion?
answer:
Do I ship Sansa with some guy who’s like twice her age just because he’s not her rapist or sadistic abuser and is ‘nice’ to her?? Um no. I know the showrunners have the bar so low it’s touching the ground, but c’mon

I don’t mind them becoming friends but I don’t romantically ship them at all.

Why game of thrones look so miserable”

You know your country is salty when they write articles about the got quality.

blog.name: secksyboijon
blog.title: Untitled
blog.description: I love a lot of fuckin shit

summary:
Y'know....
All the Gendrya fans are like the evils in Pandora's box, the Reunion and all the talking they did was the key, and...
body:
Y'know….

All the Gendrya fans are like the evils in Pandora’s box, the Reunion and all the talking they did was the key, and that scene where they fucked was the hand to unlock it and all of us bastards came rushing out like the fucking tsunami of Whights in 8.03 that gave me World War Z Flashbacks

(ps this is the cover for my story, if you don’t like Ao3 check it out on wattpad by the same name)
